Award.AwardTitle: Herbivores in Disguise--the Wolf In Sheep's Clothing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants face an onslaught of potential invaders. In order to mount successful defenses, plants specifically recognize the threat (microbe vs. herbivore) and mount the proper defense. As effective counterploys, herbivores may detoxify the chemical defenses of plants or even avoid these plants. The central hypothesis is that as a counterploy, some herbivores present themselves in "disguise" and thus avoid detection by plants. The investigators will study herbivores that exploit their gut bacteria by releasing them in their oral secretions on plants, and thus be "mistakenly" recognized as microbes. Consequently, plants turn on the incorrect defenses that are largely ineffective against these intruders. The hypothesis will be tested using biochemical and molecular approaches to identify specific oral bacteria responsible for suppressing plant defenses. The experimental system will include leaf-feeding beetles and caterpillars and several crop species (corn, soybeans, tomato) and wild plant species (wild Solanum, poplar, and Arabidopsis). The bacterial community of the oral secretions of the herbivores will be altered by dietary antibiotics and then tested for activity in suppressing plant defenses. Specific bacteria responsible for suppression will be identified and fully characterized at the molecular level. Thus the research work is transformative in expanding the understanding of how herbivores exploit their host plants.

Because the study system involves key agricultural crops/pests, the knowledge gained from these studies may have far-reaching impact on informing sustainable pest management. The role of the gut microflora of pest insects has largely been ignored, but could offer new targets that for pest management. The PIs will incorporate this research in an undergraduate course and interactive educational modules will be presented at various outreach opportunities for K-12 students. The investigators will also build upon previous outreach/educational programs to underserved audiences including children with Autism Spectrum Disorder and African-Americans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plants face an onslaught of potential invading pests, but plants can mount an effective defensive response against these threats.   These induced defenses are regulated by include jasmonic acid (JA)-regulated pathway, which defends against herbivorous insects, and the salicylic acid (SA)-regulated pathway, which primarily responds to microbial pathogens.  These pathways are often antagonistic, which requires that plants must specifically recognize the threat (microbe vs. herbivore), elicit the appropriate signaling pathway (e.g., salicylic acid vs. jasmonic acid). As effective counterploys, herbivores may disrupt the defense signaling machinery by producing salivary effectors that suppress the jasmonic aid pathway. 

However, our research revealed that as an alternative counterploy, some herbivores may present themselves in “disguise” and thus avoid proper detection by plants.  We found that some beetles and caterpillars may exploit their gut microbes by releasing them in their oral secretions on plants, and thus be “mistakenly” recognized as microbes.  Consequently, plants turn on the incorrect signaling pathway and express defenses that are largely ineffective against these intruders.  This alternative counterploy had been largely overlooked, but may represent a far more commonly used strategy by certain groups of insect herbivores than previously recognized.  In several studies with the Colorado potato beetle and its closely related cousin, the False potato beetle, we found that specific bacteria in their oral secretions could suppress defenses in cultivated tomato and potato and also in a wild host plant, horsenettle.  Specific microbial factors from these bacteria such as flagellin are recognized by the plants and trigger the salicylic acid pathway, which effectively suppressed the jasmonic acid regulated defenses.  We observed similar phenomenon in other insects such as the Fall armyworm that may regurgitate their gut bacteria onto the plant during feeding. Consequently, we believe this may be a relatively wide spread phenomenon that herbivores may exploit to overcome the induced defenses of their host plants.

Several Ph. D. students worked on part of this project during their graduate programs and have since graduated and are currently working in permanent research positions or are postdoctoral scholars.  There were several undergraduates from minority serving institutions that participated in summer research projects and one of them will be entering the Ph.D. program at Penn State for Fall 2017.  The research was disseminated broadly in professional society meetings across multiple disciplines.  Several review articles were written that were largely built on the research findings of this project. .  Interactive educational modules were presented at two annual events held at Penn State, the Great Insect Fair sponsored by the Dept. of Entomology, which typically attracts >6,000 K through 12 students and at Ag Progress Days held by the College of Agriculture that was attended by ~45,000 individuals. Because the study system involves some key agricultural crops/pests, the knowledge gained from these crop-pest interactions will inform novel approaches for sustainable pest management.  The role of the gut microflora of pest insects has largely been ignored in considering pest management strategies, but could offer new pest targets that may be manipulated for the benefit of agriculture.
